content.description:
Tricky liebacks, small feet, eases off at the end.

Same start as ready to strike
Bolts

climbs.name: Bite Me Not
climbs.fa: J. Moore, B. Curtis, G. Salter 1997

content.description:
Bite Me Not - 5.10b ** 65' F(6b)
Start 10' left of Sidewinder; climb the face to a crack and then straight up with long reaches to the 2 bolt anchors below the loose top. Fun and safe despite the seemingly loose sections.

At the far south end of the east face (left of the Ready To Strike corner).
6 bolts.

Start the climb on a low bolt and follow a right traverse to gain a corner. Clip a couple of bolts and move right around the arete. Continue up edges and flakes, very Skaha-style to the anchors.

Route is one line right of On Yer Bike. It tackles the obvious left facing corner before gaining the arete.
~7 bolts and fixed chains for an anchor.

This is the second pitch (continuation) of Chameleon, and goes on bomber gear placements. Fire up fun face holds and excellent jams. Can be combined with P1 as a single long pitch with a 70m.

Second pitch of Chameleon. Continue straight up from the P1 anchor and follow the obvious tight hands crack to an anchor.
Singles from a blue alien to a #1 BD Cam. Fixed chains for an anchor.

A fun, technical adventure up the vertical face left of the massive dihedral (Ready to Strike) of the Diamondback. Start just left of a second, smaller dihedral left of the main wall and follow the bolt line up through a few small overlaps to a nice little sting in the tail at the top of the route.

Just left of the smaller dihedral, and just right of Sidewinder (5.10c). Super chalked.
11 bolts.

The small left facing corner which leads to face climbing.

Small dihedral just left of main (Ready To Strike) corner.
A small assorted rack of nuts and cams, 4 bolts on upper face. Shares top chains with Rattle and Hum.

Steep moves at the arete see you through the first three bolts and the roof, bringing you onto the face above. Follow the edges past seven bolts, a thin crux, and to the anchor on the wall past the top of the climbing.

The climb starts on the arete on the left side of the deep chimney feature.
10 bolts and chain anchor

Shares the first two bolts with Ready to Strike (5.10a trad), then goes right.

The obvious corner on the South Face, to the right of the super chalked Sidewinder (5.10c) and Cytotoxic (5.11a).
11 bolts to chain anchors.  An optional cam could be placed between the 2nd and 3rd bolt.

Start on a block with a good set of jugs. Climb steeply through three roofs on small holds and some high feet. Afterwards the angle eases and so does the pump, but it's still pretty techy and definitely not over.



The leftmost side of the steep section of the wall, without going so far that you're climbing in a slight corner.

11 bolts, chain anchor

Almost too much fun, if that can be a thing. Easily the best route at the cliff. Start down and right of Ready To Strike (the massive corner that defines the cliff). This beauty of a route climbs the obvious crack feature straight up through a series of roofs. Burl through the bottom and hang tough (knowing how to ringlock helps, though not necessary) through the first three or four bolts. To keep you honest, there's a little bite as you crest the final roof- and then the chains are yours! Enjoy!

Past the big corner and the Ready to Strike Wal, look for the obvious crack up through the roofs.
6 bolts.

An absolute masterpiece of a climb! Clip from the deck and pull the opening roof on big holds to gain the face. Climb the beautifully elegant face on thin edges for 29 more meters. 



The first line right of the steep overhang- starts just above a stump covered by a big block on the ledge. Look for the bolt you can reach from the block. 

14 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

climbs.name: Rattle and Hum
climbs.fa: Gary Wolkoff, Bert Marchant, Rob Shaw 1993

content.description:
A nice 5.9.

Just left of Ready to Strike (5.10a trad), which is in the dihedral.
Mostly small rack.

Classic trad climb at Skaha that sucks up gear.

The obvious corner crack to the right of the super chalked routes of Sidewinder (5.10c) and Cytotoxic (5.11a).
2 bolts to start, then gear to a chain anchors.

A great face climb! Buckets, sidepulls, crimps, sloper footholds: this route has it all. Crux is in the middle of the route.

Third route from the left on the East Face (Ready to Strike Wall). Super chalked. To the left of Cytotoxic (5.11a).
7 bolts.

The East Face is a combination of the Ready to Strike, Viper, and Nutcraft Walls in Howie Richardson's guidebook. Ready to Strike Wall in particular is home to a few Skaha classics, including Sidewinder (5.10c), Cytotoxic (5.11a), and Ready to Strike (5.10a trad).  
  
 This crag is popular on busy days. It's sunny in the morning and shady in the afternoon.
